supporting_components: React Hook Integration for Native Events
Mobile-first UI/UX Design (Safe Areas, Touch Targets)
App Bundling and Code Signing Basics

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase focuses on the fundamental bridge between your React code and the native mobile environment, which is the most critical hurdle for any web developer moving into the Capacitor ecosystem. You will spend your time configuring the underlying native platforms to ensure your build process is stable and predictable before you attempt to implement more complex features.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Configuring React projects for iOS/Android and synchronizing web assets via Capacitor CLI.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Implementing live-reload workflows to test UI changes on physical devices or simulators.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Running standard npm scripts and modifying React components for mobile responsiveness.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Resolving Gradle sync errors and Xcode build failures related to CocoaPods or architecture mismatches.

objective: Successful 'npx cap sync' with zero console errors
Initial app launch on a physical device within 2 minutes of build start
subjective: Reduced anxiety when opening Android Studio or Xcode
Clarity on the file structure of the 'ios' and 'android' folders

practice_cycles.focus_summary: Core Plugin Integration and Permission Handling
practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase moves you into the practical application of core native APIs like the Camera, Filesystem, and Geolocation to ensure your React components can interact effectively with hardware. You will encounter your first real challenges with platform-specific permissions and asynchronous native responses, which are necessary steps to building responsive and reliable cross-platform mobile applications.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Building small functional modules that utilize @capacitor/camera and @capacitor/storage within React hooks.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Mapping platform-specific logic for permission requests and handling 'denied' states in the UI.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Using Capacitor plugins as standard TypeScript promises within your existing React logic.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Managing local file URIs and converting base64 data to native blobs for filesystem storage.

objective: Implementation of at least 4 core plugins in a single test application
Zero uncaught runtime exceptions during native API calls
subjective: Confidence in managing the lifecycle of native hardware requests
Intuition for when to use Capacitor vs a standard Web API

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase targets your transition into advanced architectural patterns by diving into custom plugin development and deep performance tuning for both iOS and Android targets. You will learn to write or modify native code to suit your specific project needs, ensuring that your applications are not limited by the standard plugin library available in the ecosystem.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Prototyping a custom native bridge to access a non-standard platform feature using Swift or Java.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Optimizing web-to-native communication frequency to reduce overhead in data-intensive applications.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Consuming existing plugins and styling components for different screen densities.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Writing boilerplate native code to expose a specific platform SDK functionality to the React layer.

objective: Successful execution of a custom native method called from a React component
App bundle size reduction through asset optimization and dead code elimination
subjective: Feeling like a mobile developer rather than just a web developer using a wrapper
Ability to troubleshoot native stack traces without external assistance

objective: Time spent resolving environment-related build issues per week
Number of native features successfully integrated into a production-ready build
Lighthouse performance scores for the web assets within the native webview
subjective: Self-rated comfort level with native platform IDEs (Xcode/Android Studio)
Ease of translating a mobile-specific requirement into a technical implementation plan
Consistency of the practice habit over the 16-week duration

architect_notes: The 6-hour weekly commitment is tight; focusing on one platform (iOS or Android) at a time during Cycle 1 will prevent burnout.
You should treat the native IDEs as secondary tools, not enemies; getting familiar with their logs early is the key to advanced mastery.
Your progress will be non-linear; expect environmental issues to consume 50% of your time in the first month.

practice_logs.activity: Configuring React projects for ios like java
Implementing live-reload workflows to test UI changes but its not working
Fundamental bridge between your React code and the native mobile environment and it was hard
synchronizing web assets via Capacitor CLI was hard
Running standard npm scripts was the only simple thing there

friction_signals: Rapid escalation of difficulty rating from 7 to 10
Task failure reported in final session ('its not working')
High fatigue reported (10/10) following environmental setup issues
positive_signals: Direct engagement with primary and secondary strategy activities
Persistent effort across three consecutive sub-sessions despite increasing difficulty

analysis_notes: User reached maximum fatigue (10) and difficulty (10) ratings within 93 total minutes of practice.
The session sequence shows a linear decline in effectiveness, ending in a failed implementation of live-reload workflows.
While environmental friction was expected by the strategy, the physiological and psychological impact (10/10 fatigue) suggests the current intensity is unsustainable.
The 10/10 difficulty rating indicates the user is operating at their absolute limit, increasing the risk of burnout early in Cycle 1.

friction_signals: Capacitor CLI synchronization recorded at 9/10 difficulty
Fatigue spike to 8/10 during platform synchronization task
positive_signals: Successful execution of primary cycle activities (Sync, Bridge)
Effective recovery in session 3 by pivot to 'comfortable' npm scripts
Adherence to Cycle 1 focus despite environmental difficulty

analysis_notes: The 9/10 difficulty and 8/10 fatigue in session 2 indicate significant friction, yet this is explicitly predicted in the strategy's architect notes regarding environmental issues.
Session 3 demonstrates successful self-regulation: the user moved to 'comfortable' tasks, resulting in a fatigue drop from 8 to 4.
The user is operating within the intended 'challenging' profile for Cycle 1; current signals do not yet constitute persistent misalignment.
Optimization is not warranted because the high difficulty is localized to expected hurdles and followed by a recovery session.

constraints.learning_style: Project-based application with a focus on native-web interoperability
constraints.dropout_risk: Environmental configuration friction and platform-specific debugging hurdles
